repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Running the TUI as an external process (commit https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/24488169564c39a506c235bf6a33b8e23a8cb528) causes issues with the reporting of startup times (`--startuptime`), as there are now two different processes running concurrently, each writing its relative times to the same file simultaneously (see issue #23036).

This can potentially mess up the formatting of the file and makes its interpretation very hard as it interleaves two startup sequences into the same timeline.

There are multiple solutions to this problem:

### 1. Only report the startup times of the "main" process (recognized by `--embed` flag)

Pros:
* The output file will contain a single timeline (only main process writes to the file)
* Easiest to implement

Cons:
* we will lose the startup times of the TUI process

### 2. Combine the output of both processes into single timeline

Pros:
* single timeline for both processes

Cons:
* hard two implement as each process starts at a different time and has a different clock (hence, can't be modelled by same timeline)

```
clock  event
0.0     main startes
0.5     main does something
0.0     tui starts
0.7     main does something
0.3     tui does something
```

### 3. Each process has its own timeline

Pros:
* relatively easy to implement
* no loss of information

Cons:
* Multiple timelines instead of one

This MR implements option 3, meaning that we report the timeline of each process independently.
It introduces the following changes:

1. each process writes the startup times to a memory buffer first *no concurrent writing takes place)
2. when the process has finished with the initialization the buffer is flushed and appended to the report
3. the report now consists of different sections, one for each process

The new report looks like this:

```
--- Startup times for TUI process ---

times in msec
 clock   self+sourced   self:  sourced script
 clock   elapsed:              other lines

000.006  000.006: --- NVIM STARTING ---
000.428  000.422: event init
000.728  000.301: early init
...
005.880  000.713: init highlight
005.882  000.002: --- NVIM STARTED ---

--- Startup times for Main process ---

times in msec
 clock   self+sourced   self:  sourced script
 clock   elapsed:              other lines

000.006  000.006: --- NVIM STARTING ---
000.409  000.403: event init
000.557  000.148: early init
000.633  000.077: locale set
...
014.383  000.430: first screen update
014.387  000.003: --- NVIM STARTED ---
```

### Implementation notes

Originally I tried to use [open_memstream](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/open_memstream.3.html) which allocates a dynamic memory buffer where each process can write its the startup times, but I had the sad realization that it doesn't exist on windows....

However, if we can assume that all timings fit in a large enough buffer (currently set to 8k) we can use controlled buffering (setvbuf) to delay the flushing only after the initialization has concluded.

Fix #23036

comment_data.body: Better name these `startuptime_init()` and `startuptime_finish()`
Update: I didn't realize there are already many other functions with `time_` prefix. Maybe `time_` prefix is fine then. (although not straightforward enough)
yeah, I agree. Just reverted.
This will recognize a headless instance as the TUI process.
Meanwhile it's hard to decide whether Nvim will be launched in headless mode without parsing arguments, so maybe it's necessary to parse arguments earlier?

good point. Can't we just explicitly search for the `--headless` option here?

```
bool is_main_process = hasFlagBeenSet("--headless") || hasFlagBeedSet("--embed");
```
No, there are other flags that imply headless mode.

In that case the easiest solution would probably be to rename the process in the report to something like "Primary/TUI". In that case in case of headless mode this will be the primary process, otherwise its the TUI process.
Then the variable should be called `is_embedded_process` instead of `is_main_process`.
yes, agree with you
It's "embedded", not "embeded"
oops, english is hard ;)
I think this comment can just be deleted. It's quite obvious what the code does.
This comment now also needs change.
done
done

Avoid unnecessary entropy. The option is named `--startuptime`.
```suggestion
EXTERN char *startuptime_buf INIT(= NULL); // --startuptime buffer
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -977,6 +977,8 @@ EXTERN const char bot_top_msg[] INIT(= N_("search hit BOTTOM, continuing at TOP"
 EXTERN const char line_msg[] INIT(= N_(" line "));
 
 EXTERN FILE *time_fd INIT(= NULL);  // where to write startup timing
+#define STARTUP_TIME_BUF_SIZE 8192
+EXTERN char *startup_time_buf INIT(= NULL); // startup timing buffer

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
• |--startuptime| reports the startup times for both processes (TUI + server) as separate sections.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -393,6 +393,8 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
 • |:checkhealth| buffer can now be opened in a split window using modifiers like
   |:vertical|, |:horizontal| and |:botright|.
 
+• `--startuptime` now reports the startup times per process individually.

comment_data.body: `init_startuptime` is called after `init_params`. Can you use the existing `embedded_mode` instead of re-scanning the args?
Is there any more insight (in the code comment) that can be given in the comment here about how `setvbuf` is being leveraged? It's somewhat subtle (and not common in the codebase).
might as well move this into `time_finish` also? But leave the comment lines here.
just for my own understanding, `|foo|` is a link to the help, right? How can I know when I need to use `|foo|`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -393,6 +393,8 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
 • |:checkhealth| buffer can now be opened in a split window using modifiers like
   |:vertical|, |:horizontal| and |:botright|.
 
+• `--startuptime` now reports the startup times per process individually.

comment_data.body:
Ah sorry I was thinking of `command_line_scan`. 

I guess we can't move this down, since the profiling needs to start here. We could set `embedded_mode` here and remove the duplicate logic from `command_line_scan` ... not sure if that helps anything. 

Can leave this as-is for now.

Is "primary" used anywhere else? Don't think that will help anyone by introducing extra jargon.
```suggestion
      time_init(paramp->argv[i + 1], embedded_mode ? "Embedded/server" : "TUI/client");
```

the help docs give lots of examples :) 

use `|tag|` whenever there is a `*tag*` defined somewhere.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -393,6 +393,8 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
 • |:checkhealth| buffer can now be opened in a split window using modifiers like
   |:vertical|, |:horizontal| and |:botright|.
 
+• `--startuptime` now reports the startup times per process individually.

comment_data.body: yes, I was very unsure on how to call the processes in the report. My first approach was to name "TUI" the client process and "Main" the server, however @zeertzjq correctly realized that the name "TUI" breaks the moment nvim is invoked in headless mode. That's why I started to think in more general terms like, "primary" or "secondary" process, to account for the headless scenario.
tried to give more information in the comment
`TUI/client` addresses that edge-case.

variables in small scopes really don't need such verbose names.
```suggestion
  bool is_embed = false;
```
I don't think it's "client" as headless instance are usually servers.

True. I retract my request in that case. The old code LGTM:

    time_init(paramp->argv[i + 1], is_embed ? "Embedded" : "Primary/TUI");
changed
changed
done

```suggestion
• |--startuptime| reports the startup times for both processes (TUI + server) as separate sections.

==============================================================================
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -415,6 +415,7 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
 
 • 'errorfile' (|-q|) accepts `-` as an alias for stdin.
 
+• |--startuptime| reports the startup times for both processes (TUI + server) as separate sections.
 ==============================================================================

comment_regular_data.body: Is there an extra assert you can add to the existing test for `--startuptime`, to cover the change in this PR : https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/95cbedaa1798a7c1489b68dd60380a41443ed34b/test/functional/core/startup_spec.lua#L70-L78

title: fix(startuptime): multiprocess startuptime
